thread.title: 'Armed police raid flat' in Birmingham as Britain remains on high alert following Westminster terror attack
thread.title_full: 'Armed police raid flat' in Birmingham as Britain remains on high alert following Westminster terror attack

author: Steve Robson
title: 'Armed police raid flat' in Birmingham as Britain remains on high alert following Westminster terror attack
text:
News 'Armed police raid flat' in Birmingham as Britain remains on high alert following Westminster terror attack Large scene cordoned off amid claims car used in attack which killed four and injured 40 rented in Birmingham Share Police remain at an address (Photo: SWNS - Birmingham + 44(0)1179066) Share Get politics   Thank you for subscribing!   
Armed officers reportedly raided a flat in Birmingham last night as Britain remains tense following a terror attack in Westminster. 
A large scene was cordoned off around an address on Hagley Road, a main road in the Edgbaston area of the city, for several hours at around 10.30pm. 
There were reports of armed officers involved. 
West Midlands Police would say only that an incident was "ongoing" and directed further inquiries to Scotland Yard. (Photo: SWNS) 
The Met Police could not comment due to "operational reasons". 
At around 1am on Thursday, roads were reopened. 
Uniformed officers remained outside a door between two businesses. Read More 
It is believed to lead to at least one flat above the row of shops. 
Police activity appeared to continue through the night. 
There was no immediate information to connect the incident to yesterday's terror attack in London which left four people dead and more than 40 injured. (Photo: SWNS) (Photo: SWNS) (Photo: SWNS) 
But the BBC Newsnight programme did claim that the Hyundai car used in the attack was rented from a branch of Enterprise in Birmingham last Thursday. 
A man drove a 4x4 vehicle onto Westminster Bridge and ploughed into pedestrians before crashing into a gate near the Houses of Parliament at around 2.40pm. 
He then fatally stabbed unarmed officer PC Keith Palmer, 48, before he was shot dead by armed police yards away. 
The attacker has not been identified. 
The Met Police are treating the incident as an act of terrorism. Like us on Facebook
